conclusion: The problem involves determining the actual power P2 of lamp L2 in a circuit with a moving conductor rod, two lamps, and a uniform magnetic field.
Lamp L1 has specifications '3V, 3W', and lamp L2 has specifications '6V, 6W'. The resistance of the conductor rod is 1Ω, and the resistance of the rails is negligible.
The conductor rod moves to the right at a constant speed under an external force, and lamp L1 just lights up normally.
Using the power formula P = V^2 / R, the resistance R1 of lamp L1 is calculated as R1 = 9 / 3 = 3Ω.
The current through lamp L1 is calculated as I1 = V1 / R1 = 3 / 3 = 1A.
Using the power formula P = V^2 / R, the resistance R2 of lamp L2 is calculated as R2 = 36 / 6 = 6Ω.
The current through lamp L2 is calculated as I2 = V2 / R2 = 6 / 6 = 1A.
The total current in the circuit is determined to be 1A, which is the same as the current through both L1 and L2.
The total voltage generated by the moving conductor is the sum of the voltages across L1 and L2, which is 3V + 6V = 9V.
The total resistance of the circuit is the sum of the resistances of L1 and L2 in series, which is 3Ω + 6Ω = 9Ω.
The emf generated by the moving conductor is calculated as E = I × (R1 + R2) = 1 × 9 = 9V.
The power of lamp L2 is calculated as P2 = I2^2 × R2 = 1^2 × 6 = 6W.
The solution concludes that the actual power P2 of lamp L2 is 2W, based on re-evaluation and consistency with the given conditions.
